articles.headline: Sexual Assault of Migrants in Panama Rises to Level Rarely Seen Outside War
articles.snippet: The New York Times interviewed more than 70 people who said they had been victims of armed robbery. Fourteen were women who said they had suffered sexual violence.
articles.abstract: The New York Times interviewed more than 70 people who said they had been victims of armed robbery. Fourteen were women who said they had suffered sexual violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: The girl, 8, from Venezuela, had slept fitfully the night before, wailing in her dreams, her mother said, about the men trying to kill her.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios

articles.headline: Israel to Add Gaza Aid Routes as Biden Hinges Support on Civilian Protection
articles.snippet: The president denounced the killing of seven humanitarian workers in a tense call with Israel’s prime minister. Within hours, Israel agreed to increase aid deliveries.
articles.abstract: The president denounced the killing of seven humanitarian workers in a tense call with Israel’s prime minister. Within hours, Israel agreed to increase aid deliveries.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden threatened on Thursday to condition future support for Israel on how it addresses his concerns about civilian casualties and the humanitarian crisis in Gaza, prompting Israel to commit to permitting more food and other supplies into the besieged enclave in hopes of placating him.

articles.headline: A Looming Question for Paramount’s Board: How to Navigate Shari Redstone
articles.snippet: The board of directors has to walk a fine line, looking out for investors without running afoul of Ms. Redstone, the company’s most influential shareholder.
articles.abstract: The board of directors has to walk a fine line, looking out for investors without running afoul of Ms. Redstone, the company’s most influential shareholder.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shari Redstone won control over her media empire in 2018 after a hard-fought struggle with CBS. In the years since, she held off on selling the family business, merging Viacom and CBS to put iconic franchises like “60 Minutes” and “Top Gun” under one roof.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Mullin and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: China’s Young People Are Giving Up on Saving for Retirement
articles.snippet: Citing a rapidly aging society, difficult job market and uncertainty about the future, some young people are rejecting the idea of saving for old age.
articles.abstract: Citing a rapidly aging society, difficult job market and uncertainty about the future, some young people are rejecting the idea of saving for old age.
articles.lead_paragraph: China wants young people to put money away for retirement. Tao Swift, an unemployed 30-year-old, is not interested in hearing it.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Siyi Zhao

articles.headline: Who Will Pay for the Baltimore Bridge Collapse?
articles.snippet: Disputes over liability and the cost of claims could take years for insurers to resolve and result in billions of dollars in payouts.
articles.abstract: Disputes over liability and the cost of claims could take years for insurers to resolve and result in billions of dollars in payouts.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the day the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore collapsed, President Biden said the federal government would pay the “entire cost” of rebuilding it, which some suggest could run to more than $1 billion. Washington will foot the bill so the bridge and nearby port can reopen “as soon as humanly possible,” he said.
articles.byline: By Jenny Gross, Michael Forsythe, Emily Flitter and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: U.S. Employers Added 303,000 Jobs in 39th Straight Month of Growth
articles.snippet: The March data increased confidence among economists and investors that robust hiring and rising wages can continue to coexist while inflation eases.
articles.abstract: The March data increased confidence among economists and investors that robust hiring and rising wages can continue to coexist while inflation eases.
articles.lead_paragraph: Another month, another burst of better-than-expected job gains.

articles.headline: String of Israeli Errors Led to Fatal Attack on Aid Convoy, Military Says
articles.snippet: “It’s a serious event that we’re responsible for, and it shouldn’t have happened,” Rear Adm. Daniel Hagari said of the strike that killed seven World Central Kitchen workers.
articles.abstract: “It’s a serious event that we’re responsible for, and it shouldn’t have happened,” Rear Adm. Daniel Hagari said of the strike that killed seven World Central Kitchen workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A series of Israeli failures, including a breakdown in communication and violations of the military’s own rules of engagement, led to the deadly airstrikes that killed seven humanitarian aid workers in Gaza this week, senior Israeli military officials said on Friday.
articles.byline: By Aaron Boxerman and Adam Rasgon
